      • add

        public void add(int key,
       long value)
        Adds value to index. Values will be stored in same order as they were added.
        Parameters:
        key - value of key
        value - value

      • getValueQuick

        public long getValueQuick(int key,
                 int i)
        Searches for indexed value of a key. This method will lookup newest values much faster then oldest. If either key doesn't exist in index or value index is out of bounds an exception will be thrown.
        Parameters:
        key - value of key
        i - index of key value to get.
        Returns:
        long value for given index.

      • contains

        public boolean contains(int key)
        Checks if key exists in index. Use case for this method is in combination with #lastValue method.
        Parameters:
        key - value of key
        Returns:
        true if key has any values associated with it, false otherwise.

      • getValueCount

        public int getValueCount(int key)
        Counts values for a key. Uses case for this method is best illustrated by this code examples:

        int c = index.getValueCount(key) for (int i = c-1; i >=0; i--) { long value = index.getValueQuick(key, i) }

        Note that the loop above is deliberately in reverse order, as #getValueQuick performance diminishes the father away from last the current index is.

        If it is your intention to iterate through all index values consider #getValues, as it offers better for this use case.

        Parameters:
        key - value of key
        Returns:
        number of values associated with key. 0 if either key doesn't exist or it doesn't have values.

      • lastValue

        public long lastValue(int key)
        Gets last value for key. If key doesn't exist in index an exception will be thrown. This method has to be used in combination with #contains. E.g. check if index contains key and if it does - get last value. Thrown exception is intended to point out breaking of this convention.
        Parameters:
        key - value of key
        Returns:
        value

      • getValues

        public LongArrayList getValues(int key)
        List of values for key. Values are in order they were added. This method is best for use cases where you are most likely to process all records from index. In cases where you need last few records from index #getValueCount and #getValueQuick are faster and more memory efficient.
        Parameters:
        key - key value
        Returns:
        List of values or exception if key doesn't exist.

      • getValues

        public void getValues(int key,
             LongArrayList values)
        This method does the same thing as #getValues(int key). In addition it lets calling party to reuse their array for memory efficiency.
        Parameters:
        key - key value
        values - the array to copy values to. The contents of this array will be overwritten with new values beginning from 0 index.

      • cachedCursor

        public KVIndex.IndexCursor cachedCursor(int key)

      • size

        public long size()
        Size of index is in fact maximum of all row IDs. This is useful to keep it in same units of measure as size of columns.
        Returns:
        max of all row IDs in index.

      • close

        public void close()
        Closes underlying files.
        Specified by:
        close in interface Closeable
        Specified by:
        close in interface AutoCloseable

      • compact

        public void compact()
             throws JournalException
        Removes empty space at end of index files. This is useful if your chosen file copy routine does not support sparse files, e.g. where size of file content significantly smaller then file size in directory catalogue.
        Throws:
        JournalException

      • truncate

        public void truncate(long size)
